title: Applying Cognitive Load Theory in Nursing Education: Integrated Design of Collaborative and Problem-Based Learning

context.prior_knowledge: Completion of advanced studies and experience in executing high-level projects
context.additional_context: Training for professional nurses within medical institutions, conducted in a BYOD environment.

learning_goals: Learners can design step-by-step problem-solving strategies from simple to complex by applying Cognitive Load Theory.
In a collaborative learning environment, learners can analyze core issues in nursing scenarios through role division with team members.
Utilizing Problem-Based Learning (PBL), learners evaluate complex nursing cases reflecting real clinical situations.

Within one week, learners measure mental effort levels ≥3 times using cognitive load monitoring tools (NASA-TLX survey) and propose ≥2 adjustments to reduce intrinsic load (task segmentation, interface simplification)

Within one week, teams develop nursing education module prototypes applying cognitive load minimization strategies (chunking, visual hierarchy, feedback systems), submitting deliverables meeting predefined criteria (usability test ≥80% pass rate, cognitive load survey ≥4/5)
difficulty: Hard - Complex requirements with multiple constraints
